data.title: Steve Carell Has Replaced Bruce Willis in Woody Allen’s Latest
data.meta_description: Because the two are essentially interchangeable
data.text:
Bruce Willis, whose favorite thing used to be shattering plate-glass windows with his body, is doing a new thing lately: Signing on for a movie, then not actually making said movie. He kick-started this fun, late-in-life trend with The Expendables 3, which, as we reported in 2013, saw Willis replaced unceremoniously by Harrison Ford, much to Sylvester Stallone’s evident glee. Next up was Wake, a thriller in which he was set to star as a “sociopath with no fear.” But this April, after the film had issues with financing because “a certain producer would not stand down from the picture,” Willis dropped out, citing another commitment.

Last week, Willis exited Woody Allen’s latest movie, again blaming scheduling conflicts, this time with his forthcoming stint on Broadway in an adaptation of Stephen King’s Misery. (Maybe someone on Willis’s team should start using GCal?) Strangely, Willis was photographed on set just a day prior to his abrupt departure—meaning he either totally forgot about Misery and then was all, “Crap, I gotta go do this play, dude,” or there’s truth to some Twitter rumors about Allen’s role in his departure.

Though we may never know the truth about What Happened With Willis, Allen has already replaced him with Steve Carell. Carell, who is surely regularly mistaken for Bruce Willis at parties, is familiar with Allen’s rapid, one-film-a-year production style, having played a small part in Allen’s 2004 flick Melinda And Melinda.

Allen’s been characteristically tight-lipped about both the plot and the title of his latest. But we do know that it’s shooting this month in both New York and LA and stars Blake Lively, Parker Posey, Kristen Stewart, Jesse Eisenberg, Jeannie Berlin, Corey Stoll, Anna Camp, and Paul Schneider . . . for now.

Steve Ballmer Chases NBA Glory at Intuit Dome, the LA Clippers’ Gleaming New Home

The team owner and former Microsoft chief dreams of taking home “the Larry” and escaping the Lakers’ shadow. “We want to win every year,” Ballmer tells Vanity Fair. “It is a philosophy.”

House of the Dragon Should End After Season Three

HBO’s Game of Thrones prequel series had a mostly strong second season, but it’s time to start wrapping things up.

How Trumpworld Is Coping With the Kamala Harris Boom

In just days, the vice president has raked in more than $100 million, scored countless endorsements, started a social media phenomenon, and secured enough delegates for the nomination. “She has been totally dominating,” marveled one GOP strategist.

During his Late Show monologue, Colbert roasted Donald Trump’s running mate for the untrue (?) sofa-billy elegy currently delighting the internet.

Politics

Democrats Are Having Fun?

They just had to listen to voters.

Politics

Trump’s GOP Swings and Misses With Desperate Attacks on Kamala Harris

Republicans built a campaign around assailing Joe Biden. But now he’s out and Trumpworld can’t seem to figure out how to hit Harris besides warmed-over racist and sexist insults.

The Real Reason Matt Damon Loves Working With Casey Affleck

“You need to get every idea out,” says the star of The Instigators, in a joint interview with Affleck. “You get there a lot faster if you’re not worried about people’s feelings. So, in other words, we talk a lot of shit to each other.”
